thread.title: Jody Stahancyk 'seriously thinking' about challenging Amanda Fritz
thread.title_full: Jody Stahancyk 'seriously thinking' about challenging Amanda Fritz

author: Brad Schmidt | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Jody Stahancyk 'seriously thinking' about challenging Amanda Fritz
text:
Updated: This story has been updated with a response from Amanda Fritz. 
Marquee divorce lawyer Jody Stahancyk may challenge Portland Commissioner Amanda Fritz in the 2016 primary election. 
Stahancyk, 67, said Thursday that she's "seriously thinking" about running against Fritz, a two-term incumbent and the only woman on the City Council. 
Stahancyk said she is considering a run against Fritz – and not Commissioner Steve Novick, also up for re-election next year – after becoming frustrated that she had to wait some six weeks to speak with Fritz about a neighborhood issue. 
When the two finally talked, Stahancyk told Fritz she might challenge her. 
Stahancyk has the Rolodex and reputation that could make her the rare formidable challenger in Portland politics. No City Council incumbent has lost a re-election bid since 1992. Fritz defeated a strong challenger, then-state Rep. Mary Nolan, in the November 2012 runoff. 
If she runs, Stahancyk said her top priority will be government transparency. 
"I'm terribly concerned in the lack of transparency," she said, a worry that applies to "the entire organization" and not specifically to Fritz. 
Stahancyk opened her law firm in 1986 and has represented former U.S. Rep. David Wu and Stimson Lumber chief executive Andrew Miller in divorce cases. A former columnist for The Oregonian wrote in 2005 that she all but wrote the legal playbook for "bone-crushing, blood-squeezing (and) making big boys cry." 
Stahancyk maintains an active civic calendar and is known for her boosterism at Lincoln High School and Portland State University. Stahancyk said she's always been interested in elected office and is prepared to step away from her firm if she wins a council seat. 
A summer event at Duniway Park, near her law office, got Stahancyk thinking about a political future. Stahancyk said big events at the park, with no notice to neighbors, made parking an issue. She wanted to help by opening her parking lot. 
Stahancyk said she tried to reach Fritz, who oversees Portland Parks & Recreation, while Fritz was on vacation in August. Stahancyk said she was told Fritz's calendar was booked until Oct. 1. That day, the two spoke by phone. 
"I thought in this case, that her actions running her bureaus suggested to me that she was not listening," she said. 
Fritz said Stahancyk made "some really great suggestions" during their conversation about how to address parking and improve neighborhood communications. But Stahancyk remained frustrated with the situation, Fritz said, and at one point said: "Well, maybe I'll just run against you." 
"It didn't sound like she was serious," Fritz said. 
Now that she is serious? "It's a democracy and nobody has a right to re-election," Fritz said. "I am proud of my record and am hoping people will vote for me." 
Stahancyk is a registered Democrat but gave $5,000 to Republican Chris Dudley during his 2010 gubernatorial bid. She also contributed $250 to Tom Hughes during his run for Metro president in 2010, $250 to Democratic state Sen. Betsy Johnson in 2013 and $500 to Multnomah County Commissioner Loretta Smith in 2014. Her firm also kicked in $600 toward Charlie Hales' Portland mayoral campaign in 2012. 
Stahancyk, who lives in Northwest Portland, said she has a rule in her family: If you do something, expect to win, and when you win, do a better job than anyone expects you to do. 
"As I look at this," she said, "I will not run unless I'm convinced that I'm in a position to be able to do that." 
-- Brad Schmidt
